title: Iterating and Debugging with Claude
description: Learn how to troubleshoot errors, iterate on your project, and work through common roadblocks using Claude as your debugging partner.
learningObjectives: Interpret common error messages and know what to share with Claude
Use Claude to debug issues without understanding the underlying code
Iterate on features based on user feedback or your own ideas
Know when to start over vs. when to keep iterating

videos.title: Error Messages: What to Copy and Paste
videos.description: Teaches you to recognize different types of errors and share the right information with Claude for quick fixes.
scriptOutline: Types of errors: syntax, runtime, build, deployment
What to copy: the full error message + the file/line number
What NOT to send: your entire codebase (unless asked)
The debugging prompt template: 'I got this error... here's what I was trying to do...'
Real example: debugging a common Next.js error
talkingPoints: Red text in your terminal? That's an error — copy all of it
Error messages look scary but Claude reads them fluently
Always include: what you were doing, what you expected, what happened instead
Most errors are simple fixes — typos, missing imports, wrong versions

videos.title: Iteration Cycles: Making Your Project Better
videos.description: Shows how to take a working project and improve it feature-by-feature using Claude.
scriptOutline: The iteration mindset: ship first, perfect later
How to describe changes: 'I want to add...', 'Can we make this...', 'Users are asking for...'
Breaking big changes into small iterations
Real example: how 02Ship evolved from the first version
When to refactor vs. when to rebuild
talkingPoints: Your first version won't be perfect — that's expected
Each iteration makes it 10% better — that compounds quickly
Ship small improvements weekly rather than one big update monthly
User feedback is gold — even 'I don't like this color' is useful

videos.title: When Things Break: The Debug Workflow
videos.description: Walks through a real debugging session: from error to solution using Claude.
scriptOutline: Step 2: Check recent changes (what did you just do?)
Step 3: Ask Claude with full context
Step 4: Apply the fix and test
Step 5: If still broken, share the new error
Live debug: fixing a real issue from 02Ship development
talkingPoints: Debugging is a skill — you get better with practice
Most bugs are recent changes — undo works!
Claude can debug anything if you give it the error message
Git commits are your time machine — commit often
When really stuck, take a break — fresh eyes help

textSections.title: The Debug Prompt Template
textSections.content:
Use this template every time you hit an error:

---

I'm building [brief description of your project].

I was trying to [what you were doing — e.g., 'run npm run dev'].

I expected [what should have happened — e.g., 'the site to load at localhost:3000'].

Instead, I got this error:

```
[paste the full error message here]
```

Here's the relevant code (if applicable):

```
[paste the file or section mentioned in the error]
```

Can you help me fix this?

---

This gives Claude everything it needs to diagnose the issue.

textSections.title: Common Errors and What They Mean
textSections.content:
**'Module not found'** → You're missing a dependency. Run `npm install [package-name]`

**'Port 3000 is already in use'** → Something's already running. Close other terminals or use a different port.

**'Unexpected token'** → Syntax error (usually a typo). Check the line number mentioned.

**'Cannot read property of undefined'** → You're trying to use data that doesn't exist yet. Claude will show you how to add a safety check.

**Build errors (during `npm run build`)** → Often TypeScript type issues or missing environment variables.

**Deployment errors (Vercel/Netlify)** → Usually environment variables or build commands.

textSections.title: Iteration Best Practices
textSections.content:
**1. One change at a time**
Don't add 5 features at once — you won't know what broke what.

**2. Test immediately**
After each change, run the app and verify it works.

**3. Commit working states**
`git commit -m 'Added user login'` — now you can always go back.

**4. Keep a changelog**
Note what you changed and why. Future you will thank you.

**5. Ask users**
Even just 1-2 people using your app will give you better ideas than you had alone.

textSections.title: When to Start Over
textSections.content:
**Keep iterating if:**
- The core structure is sound
- You're just tweaking features or design
- The codebase still makes sense to you

**Consider rebuilding if:**
- You've lost track of what does what
- Every change breaks 3 other things
- Your initial prompt was way too vague
- You've learned so much that you'd build it differently now

**The 02Ship rule:** If it takes longer to fix than to rebuild, rebuild. Your prompts are better now anyway!

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Error:** Something went wrong — the code can't run

**Warning:** Something might be wrong — the code runs but could be better

**Debugging:** The process of finding and fixing errors

**Iteration:** Making incremental improvements to a working project

**Refactor:** Rewriting code to be cleaner/better without changing what it does

**Rollback:** Reverting to a previous working version (via git)

commonMistakes.mistake: Only sharing part of the error message
commonMistakes.explanation: Claude needs the FULL error including stack trace to diagnose properly.
You won't know which change caused the issue. One at a time!
Git is your safety net — commit every time something works.
Most errors are solvable in 1-2 Claude exchanges. Stick with it.
Starting over means losing all your progress. Debug first, rebuild only if truly stuck.

reflectionQuestions: Think about the last time something broke (in life, not just code). What was your debugging process? How is it similar to debugging code?
What's the most useful error message you've encountered so far? What made it helpful?
When you hit a roadblock, do you tend to push through or take a break? What works better for you?

exercises.title: Break It on Purpose
exercises.description: Intentionally create an error in your project, then use Claude to fix it. This builds confidence in debugging.
exercises.output: Documentation of: (1) What you broke, (2) The error message, (3) Your debug prompt to Claude, (4) How you fixed it
successCriteria: Successfully created an error (e.g., deleted an import, typo'd a variable)
Wrote a debug prompt using the template
Fixed the issue based on Claude's response

exercises.title: Feature Iteration
exercises.description: Take your working project from Lesson 1 and add one small improvement using Claude.
exercises.output: A git commit showing: (1) What you added, (2) The prompt you used, (3) Testing notes (does it work?)
successCriteria: Chose a small, specific improvement (e.g., 'add a footer', 'change button color')
Wrote a clear prompt describing the change

exercises.title: Debug a Real Issue
exercises.description: If you have a real error in your project, debug it with Claude. If not, use a provided error scenario.
exercises.output: Debug journal containing: (1) The error, (2) Your hypothesis about the cause, (3) Claude exchange, (4) The solution, (5) What you learned
successCriteria: Made an educated guess about the cause (even if wrong!)
Worked with Claude through at least one iteration
Resolved the issue or identified next steps
Reflected on what this taught you about your project

instructorNotes: This lesson builds real confidence — students who debug successfully feel empowered.
For live sessions: Do a 'debug along' where everyone breaks their project in the same way, then races to fix it.
Common anxiety: 'I broke everything!' Reassure them git exists for this reason.
Self-paced tip: Encourage students to keep a 'debug log' — future reference gold.
Time check: Exercise 3 can run long if they hit a hard bug — budget buffer time or make it async homework.
Bonus: Create a 'hall of fame' for the most creative intentional bugs in Exercise 1.
